subject: Re: [junit] Order of execution for tests
msgSnippet: Hi David, ... This doesn t seem very optimal since the knowledge can only be gained when tests fail, which won t be the case most of the time. Again, why leave
messageBody:
Hi David,

On Wed, Jan 6, 2010 at 10:08 AM, David Saff <david@...> wrote:

>
>
> Rocco,
>
> Note that these kinds of dependencies could be dynamically inferred
> over time. With a complete history of pass/fail patterns, a core
> runner could notice that test B never passes when test A fails, and
> that test A is failing today, and thus, mark B as "Skipped (98%
> confidence of no new information after testA failed)"
>
> This seems like a real win over manual dependency annotation, and I'd
> be delighted to take a look at it if there were enough users (usual
> rules--create a github issue, and vote, vote, vote)
>
This doesn't seem very optimal since the knowledge can only be gained when
tests fail, which won't be the case most of the time.

Again, why leave this up to what seems like a difficult and unpredictable
heuristic when it's so easy for users to explicitly state their dependencies
in annotations?

--
***Cédric
*


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
